study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in masseter and anterior temporal muscle thickness in edentulous patients after receiving implant-supported fixed prostheses and compare them to dentate individuals.
results_summary: Implant-supported fixed prostheses significantly increased muscle thickness and reduced asymmetry between left and right muscles in edentulous patients, achieving similar muscle thickness to dentate individuals after six months.
population_specificity: 60 participants (30 edentulous patients receiving implants and 30 age- and sex-matched dentate individuals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the viability and feasibility of a novel treatment concept—the canine-positioned single implant mandibular overdenture (c-SIMO)—compared to the traditional midline implant overdenture.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in oral health-related quality of life, denture satisfaction, chewing efficiency, and maximum bite force, with a 100% implant success and survival rate at 1 year. Bite force was initially higher on the implant side but equalized over time, and common prosthodontic adjustments were required.
population_specificity: 15 participants with a mean age of 69.9 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of combining occlusal splint therapy with musculoskeletal physiotherapy and education versus occlusal splint therapy and education alone in chronic myogenic temporomandibular disorder (M-TMD) patients.
results_summary: The study found that adding musculoskeletal physiotherapy to education and occlusal splint therapy resulted in significant improvements in pain reduction at rest, during maximum oral opening, and during chewing, as well as improved range of motion, compared to the control group. These benefits were sustained at 3 months post-treatment.
population_specificity: Chronic myogenic temporomandibular disorder (M-TMD) patients (n=62).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the spatiotemporal distribution, treatment outcomes, and determinants of esophageal cancer in Ethiopia, including examining the controversial link between khat chewing and esophageal cancer.
results_summary: The study found conflicting reports on the association between khat chewing and esophageal cancer, with no clear consensus on its role as a risk factor. The temporal distribution of esophageal cancer was also noted as controversial.
population_specificity: Patients with esophageal cancer in Ethiopia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of non-bracket invisible orthodontic titanium alloy implant restoration on patients with dental malocclusion and arch deficiency accompanied by periodontitis and local periodontal inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that the research group (invisible orthodontic treatment without brackets) showed lower pain levels, reduced inflammatory markers, improved dental function (chewing, swallowing, speech, occlusion), and better aesthetics compared to the control group, with no significant difference in adverse events.
population_specificity: 120 patients with dental malocclusion and arch deficiency accompanied by periodontitis.
study_duration: 6 months of treatment, with a one-year follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in masticatory performance and bite force, and identify influential factors, one year after providing mandibular overdentures retained by four titanium-zirconium mini implants.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in masticatory performance and bite force at all follow-up periods compared to baseline. Flapless surgeries and less resorbed ridges were associated with better outcomes.
population_specificity: Edentulous patients receiving mandibular overdentures retained by mini implants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chewing vegetables in solid versus puree forms affects postprandial glucose metabolism and incretin secretion.
results_summary: Chewing shredded cabbage increased postprandial insulin, GIP, and GLP-1 secretion but did not affect glucose concentrations compared to consuming pureed cabbage without chewing.
population_specificity: 19 healthy young men

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify risk factors and clinical management strategies for squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity, with a focus on betel quid chewing as a significant risk factor.
results_summary: The study highlights betel quid chewing as a major risk factor for oral cavity cancer, alongside tobacco and alcohol use. It emphasizes the importance of multidisciplinary treatment approaches, including surgery and adjuvant therapies, for managing the disease.
population_specificity: Patients with squamous cell carcinoma of the oral cavity, particularly those with risk factors like betel quid chewing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of non-pharmacological interventions, including chewing gum, in reducing thirst in patients with chronic heart failure (CHF) or undergoing hemodialysis (HD).
results_summary: Meta-analyses for chewing gum showed no significant effect on thirst reduction, with non-significant results on both visual analogue scale and dialysis thirst inventory. Eleven intervention studies overall showed thirst reduction, but chewing gum specifically did not demonstrate efficacy.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic heart failure (CHF) and/or receiving hemodialysis (HD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the wear resistance of lithium-silicate ceramics, resin composite, and human teeth against different antagonists under simulated chewing conditions.
results_summary: LISI (lithium-silicate ceramic) showed superior abrasion resistance compared to EMA and FILL, with minimal material loss regardless of antagonist type. TESE (another ceramic) performed better against enamel antagonists, while FILL (resin composite) had higher material losses against ceramic antagonists.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study using material samples and human teeth).
study_duration: Not specified (thermomechanical aging via chewing simulator).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare patient satisfaction and quality of life between two implant-supported fixed prosthesis approaches (zygomatic implants + conventional implants vs. all-on-four concept) for rehabilitating atrophied maxillae, focusing on chewing and other functional outcomes.
results_summary: Both treatment groups showed high patient satisfaction in chewing and other functional aspects, with no significant differences between the two approaches except in satisfaction with surgical procedures and healing period. The study concluded that both methods are promising for functional and aesthetic rehabilitation of atrophied maxillae.
population_specificity: 36 patients with atrophic edentulous maxillae.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether oral interventions, including chewing exercises, contribute to long-term improvement in cognitive function.
results_summary: One study found improved attention and working memory in the chewing exercise group, but overall, there was a lack of conclusive evidence that oral interventions clearly improved cognitive function.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred from abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of total laryngectomy and electrolarynx use on quality of life, including chewing, in laryngeal cancer patients.
results_summary: Chewing showed the least progress among the evaluated quality-of-life items, with no statistical significance noted for swallowing, taste, and saliva. The study did not report significant improvements in chewing outcomes.
population_specificity: 31 patients (84% men, 93% aged 50+ years) who underwent total laryngectomy and used an electrolarynx.
study_duration: Data collected at 7 days and 70 days post-surgery, with electrolarynx use for at least 60 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the extent to which H-Ras expression and mutation contribute to the development and progression of oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC), particularly in individuals engaging in risk behaviors like chewing tobacco.
results_summary: The study found that H-Ras mutations, particularly in codons 12, 13, and 61, are prevalent in well-differentiated OSCC and are significantly associated with individuals who engage in multiple risk behaviors, including chewing tobacco. These mutations activate downstream signaling pathways leading to uncontrolled cell growth.
population_specificity: Individuals with oral squamous cell carcinoma (OSCC), particularly those engaging in risk behaviors like chewing tobacco.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate differences in electromyographic activity patterns of the masseter muscle during chewing based on nasal patency in children with rhinitis and asthma.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in electromyographic activity of the masseter muscle at rest or during chewing between children with low and adequate nasal patency, though a moderate but non-significant difference was noted during maximum contraction.
population_specificity: 43 children aged 5-14 years with rhinitis and/or asthma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the formation of the tooth-implant papilla and assess patient-reported outcomes, including chewing, when using Narrow Diameter Implants (NDI) in the anterior region.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in implant survival rate or complications between the 2.9 mm and 3.3 mm implants. Patient-reported outcomes, including chewing, showed higher satisfaction in the 2.9 mm group, though specific chewing efficacy was not detailed.
population_specificity: 40 patients treated with NDI in the maxillary lateral incisors and mandibular incisors.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (implant diameter: 2.9 mm and 3.3 mm).
study_duration: 12 months of follow-up after final prosthetic restoration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether maxillary reconstruction using a scapular-free flap with CAD/CAM osteotomy guide improves quality of life (QOL) outcomes, particularly in chewing, compared to reconstruction without the guide.
results_summary: The study found statistically significant improvements in chewing and other QOL domains (pain, appearance, swallowing, speech, and shoulder function) in patients who underwent reconstruction with the CAD/CAM guide compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Patients with maxillary defects, no prior surgery or lymph node involvement, and excluded those with poor oncological prognosis, deficient performance status, or preoperative chemotherapy/radiotherapy.
study_duration: Outcomes were measured 12 months after reconstruction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of chewing as a physical intervention for relieving pain after orthodontic treatment compared to other methods like LLLT, vibration, and acupuncture.
results_summary: Chewing was found to effectively relieve pain symptoms in patients after orthodontic treatment, though it was less effective than LLLT and vibration at 24 hours and less effective than acupuncture at 48 hours.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing orthodontic treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether caffeine gum improves performance in recreational runners completing 5 km parkruns.
results_summary: Caffeine gum improved 5 km parkrun performance by an average of 17.28 seconds and reduced perceived exertion by 1.21 units compared to placebo. The results were statistically significant, though environmental adjustments slightly attenuated the effect.
population_specificity: 36 recreational runners (31 male, 5 female; age 33.7 ± 10.7 years; BMI 23.1 ± 2.4 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 300 mg caffeine supplied in chewing gum.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits and harms of interventions for managing oral submucous fibrosis (OSF), a condition primarily caused by areca nut chewing.
results_summary: The study found moderate-certainty evidence that antioxidants slightly improve mouth opening at 3-6 months and reduce burning sensation, but evidence for other interventions was low or very low certainty. Adverse effects were mild and transient for systemic drugs, but serious effects occurred in one surgical intervention.
population_specificity: Adults with biopsy-confirmed oral submucous fibrosis (OSF).
study_duration: Ranged from less than 3 months to over 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss the role of chewing tobacco as a chemical factor contributing to cancer development and explore plant-based alternatives for safer treatment.
results_summary: The abstract identifies chewing tobacco as a chemical mutagen contributing to cancer but does not provide specific study results on its effects. It highlights plant-based products as potential safer alternatives with anti-carcinogenic properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on cancer causes and treatments).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between malocclusion and oral ingestion and identify tools to screen for malocclusion-related ingestion disorders.
results_summary: The review found that malocclusion severity negatively impacts oral ingestion, though causality could not be determined due to the observational nature of many studies. Orthodontic treatment should focus on improving ingestion function.
population_specificity: Subjects with malocclusion (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the qualitative literature on the experiences of living with removable dentures, focusing on patient-centered perspectives, including impacts on chewing and other aspects of daily life.
results_summary: The study identified key themes such as the impact of tooth loss on chewing and speaking, social norms around dentures, patient expectations, adaptation to dentures, and dentist-patient communication. It highlighted the need for more research on positive adaptation and oral-health-related quality of life.
population_specificity: Individuals living with removable dentures (complete or partial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess which drugs are most suitable for treating different signs of temporomandibular disorders (TMD) related to chewing and other jaw movements.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found no significant intergroup variability in drug efficacy for TMD pain, concluding there is no first-choice drug for treatment, but clinicians should tailor therapy based on pain type and cause.
population_specificity: Patients with temporomandibular disorders (TMD) experiencing jaw pain, clicks, or creaks during chewing, yawning, or speaking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate socio-demographic risk factors related to cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN), including the role of betel or tobacco chewing.
results_summary: The study found that betel or tobacco chewing was present in 28.0% of CIN cases, suggesting a potential association, but no direct efficacy or safety outcomes were assessed.
population_specificity: 50 patients with precancerous cervical lesions in Mymensingh, Bangladesh, predominantly rural, aged 30-39 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of biomechanical modeling, particularly finite element method (FEM), in predicting functional outcomes (including chewing) after mandibular reconstruction surgery.
results_summary: The study reviewed 66 computational modeling studies, primarily using FEM, to assess the biomechanical outcomes of mandibular reconstruction. It found that these models help predict functional outcomes (e.g., chewing) and tailor patient-specific treatments, with most studies focusing on bone flaps, plates/screws, and prostheses.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing mandibular reconstruction surgery for advanced head and neck cancers involving the mandible.

study_goal: To evaluate the effectiveness of a Lay Health Advisor (LHA) program on oral function (including chewing) and oral health-related quality of life (OHRQoL) among older adults in an aboriginal community.
results_summary: The LHA program significantly improved masticatory performance (chewing), swallowing, and plaque control in the experimental group compared to the control group. Additionally, the experimental group showed a significant long-term improvement in OHRQoL at the 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Aboriginal older adults residing in remote areas.
effective_dosage: One-on-one 30-minute lessons by an LHA over 4 weeks (frequency not specified).
study_duration: 4 weeks (with follow-ups at 2 weeks, 3 months, and 6 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical performance, including chewing function, of provisional single crowns made using conventional PMMA and 3D-printed workflows.
results_summary: No statistical difference was observed in patients' satisfaction regarding chewing between conventional PMMA and 3D-printed provisional crowns, though 3D-printed crowns had higher rates of catastrophic failures.
population_specificity: 33 patients receiving provisional single crowns on anterior implants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if chewing a confectionary jelly snake postoperatively could reduce the incidence of vomiting in young children after tonsillectomy.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in vomiting episodes between the chewing group and the control group within 6 hours post-operation. There were also no differences in antiemetic use or delayed discharge due to PONV up to 24 hours.
population_specificity: Children aged 2-16 years undergoing tonsillectomy.
study_duration: Within one hour of waking post-operation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chewing gum in reducing postoperative ileus and accelerating bowel function recovery after colorectal surgery.
results_summary: Chewing gum was associated with a median reduction of postoperative ileus by 45% and shortened the time to first flatus by 11.9 hours and time to defecation by 17.7 hours. It was one of the most assessed and effective interventions for improving bowel function recovery.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing colorectal surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of observing video-recorded chewing on mixing ability, cognition, daily living activities, depressive symptoms, and quality of life in older adults with dementia.
results_summary: The study found a significant improvement in cognition (Mini-Mental State Examination) for the experimental group watching chewing videos compared to the control group, with a smaller effect persisting at follow-up. No significant effects were observed for other measured outcomes.
population_specificity: Older adults with dementia residing in care facilities.
effective_dosage: Videos displayed during lunch, 5 days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify determinants of prelabor rupture of membrane, including maternal khat chewing, among pregnant women in the Jimma zone, Ethiopia.
results_summary: The study found that maternal khat chewing was a significant determinant of prelabor rupture of membrane, with an adjusted odds ratio of 3.40 (95% CI: 1.70-6.80). This suggests a strong association between khat chewing and increased risk of the condition.
population_specificity: Pregnant women attending governmental hospitals in the Jimma zone, Oromia region, Ethiopia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of interventions to prevent or cease e-cigarette use in children and adolescents, including potential effects on other tobacco products like chewing tobacco.
results_summary: No eligible RCTs were identified to assess interventions targeting e-cigarette or chewing tobacco use in children and adolescents, leaving no evidence to evaluate efficacy or safety.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents aged 19 years or younger.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether compensating curves in complete dentures impact masticatory performance and swallowing threshold in edentulous subjects.
results_summary: No differences in masticatory performance were found between dentures with and without compensating curves, but swallowing threshold improved after one month, resulting in smaller particle sizes and increased chewing rates.
population_specificity: Seven edentulous subjects, aged 64.6 ± 2.0 years.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (denture adjustment, not a supplement).
study_duration: One-week and one-month adaptation periods, with a one-week washout period.

study_goal: To investigate patients' perceptions and tolerance of autologous platelet-rich fibrin (i-PRF) injections during orthodontic canine retraction.
results_summary: Pain and swelling were significantly higher on the intervention side initially but declined sharply within 24 hours. Discomfort and chewing difficulties were transient, and the method was well-tolerated overall.
population_specificity: 21 patients requiring upper first premolar extractions for orthodontic treatment.
effective_dosage: i-PRF injected twice with a one-month interval.
study_duration: Two injections administered one month apart, with follow-up assessments up to 48 hours post-injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of non-pharmacologic interventions, including chewing gum, in managing radiation-induced dry mouth in cancer patients.
results_summary: One study included in the review examined chewing gum, but the abstract does not provide specific efficacy results for this intervention. The overall evidence for non-pharmacologic interventions was limited due to heterogeneity in interventions and outcome measurements.
population_specificity: Cancer patients with radiation-induced dry mouth.

study_goal: The study aimed to estimate the prevalence of neural tube defects (NTDs) and identify potential risk factors in Ethiopia, not to evaluate chewing.
results_summary: The study found a high pooled prevalence of NTDs in Ethiopia (71.48 per 10,000 births), linked to heredity, maternal, and environmental factors, and recommended folic acid fortification as a priority intervention.
population_specificity: Ethiopian population, including 611,064 participants from 42 studies.

study_goal: To determine the immediate effect of eccentric occlusal interferences on masticatory performance.
results_summary: Artificial eccentric interferences resulted in larger comminuted particles, indicating reduced masticatory performance, particularly under unilateral and bilateral laterotrusive, bilateral mediotrusive, and protrusive interferences. The chewing rate remained unaffected across all conditions.
population_specificity: 12 healthy dentate subjects aged 25.2 ± 3.3 years.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (occlusal interferences were fabricated and adhered to mandibular first molars).
study_duration: Immediate effect assessed per test day, with a 1-week washout period between tests.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of mechanical stress, such as betel quid chewing, in oral potentially malignant disorders, particularly oral submucous fibrosis.
results_summary: The study discusses the link between mechanical stress (e.g., betel quid chewing) and stiffness equilibrium in oral potentially malignant disorders, suggesting a possible trigger for oral submucous fibrosis. It highlights abnormal cellular networks and interactions in oral cancer but does not quantify chewing's direct effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of oral cancer and related disorders).

study_goal: To investigate the influence of prosthodontic rehabilitation, with or without dietary advice, on nutritional status in elderly patients.
results_summary: Prosthetic treatment improved chewing ability but did not consistently improve nutritional status without dietary advice. Combining dietary advice with prosthetic treatment showed improvement in nutrient intake.
population_specificity: Elderly patients aged 60 years or older with tooth loss.
study_duration: At least 1 month after prosthetic rehabilitation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare patient satisfaction, postoperative pain, inflammation, and quality of life between high-speed drilling with irrigation and low-speed drilling without irrigation for implant bed preparation.
results_summary: Low-speed drilling without irrigation was more comfortable for patients and resulted in lower postoperative pain and inflammation compared to high-speed drilling with irrigation. No significant differences in quality of life, including chewing, were observed postoperatively.
population_specificity: Sixty-six posterior single edentulous patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between different dental implant indications and oral health-related quality of life (OHRQoL), including improvements in chewing function.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in OHRQoL, particularly in chewing, appearance, and psychological concerns, with the most notable benefits observed in patients with edentulous jaws. The OHIP-G-21 scores showed statistically significant reductions post-treatment, indicating enhanced quality of life.
population_specificity: 16,253 patients with various dental implant indications (single tooth loss to edentulous jaws), aged 18-88 years, from 29 European centers.
study_duration: Data collected between 2009 and 2021, with follow-up after implant insertion and prosthodontic treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether showing patients a 3D digital prediction of their orthodontic treatment outcomes would change their expectations and satisfaction regarding chewing, speech, and oral hygiene.
results_summary: Patients' expectations for chewing improvement significantly increased after viewing the predicted alignment, but the final satisfaction with chewing was higher than the predicted outcome. The study noted these changes were not clinically significant.
population_specificity: 28 patients (18 females, 10 males, mean age 20.68 ± 1.91 years) with Class I malocclusion and moderate dental crowding requiring nonextraction orthodontic treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of implant-supported prostheses on oral function in completely edentulous adults.
results_summary: The meta-analysis showed significant improvement in oral function (bite force, masticatory performance, muscle activity, etc.) at 6-12 months post-implant therapy, with benefits sustained beyond 36 months.
population_specificity: Completely edentulous adults rehabilitated with implant-supported prostheses.
study_duration: Follow-up periods of 6-12 months, 12-36 months, and >36 months.

study_goal: To evaluate the impact of removable partial dentures (RPDs) on masticatory performance in partially edentulous subjects.
results_summary: RPDs showed a positive impact on masticatory function in most studies, with subjective evaluations reporting higher improvement (83.3%) than objective evaluations (69.5%). Bilateral free-end saddle dentures particularly benefited, with 9 out of 13 studies showing improved masticatory efficiency.
population_specificity: Partially edentulous subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight recent advances in oral or topical delivery of proteins, including chewing gums, for biologics to improve affordability and accessibility.
results_summary: The abstract discusses the advantages of oral biologics, such as reduced costs and simplified regulatory processes, but does not provide specific results on chewing's effects. It emphasizes the potential of chewing gums as a delivery method for proteins in clinical trials.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of biologics and delivery methods).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the association between esophageal dysbiosis (linked to betel nut chewing, among other factors) and esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC) progression and chemoresistance.
results_summary: The study found that betel nut chewing, along with smoking and drinking, is associated with esophageal dysbiosis, which promotes ESCC progression and chemotherapy resistance. Specific bacteria like Porphyromonas gingivalis and Fusobacterium nucleatum were implicated in carcinogenesis and drug resistance via inflammatory pathways.
population_specificity: Individuals at risk for or diagnosed with esophageal squamous cell carcinoma (ESCC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the relationship between chewing-side preference and temporomandibular disorders (TMD), including its effects on TMJ structure and potential mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that chewing-side preference is strongly correlated with TMD symptoms, leading to structural changes in the TMJ, muscle imbalances, and neurogenic mechanisms involving neuropeptides. Animal and clinical studies support these findings.
population_specificity: Humans and animals (specific populations not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine misophonia, particularly its triggers like chewing, and explore its implications for the social work profession.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that chewing is a common trigger for misophonia, eliciting strong negative emotional and physiological responses, but does not provide specific study results on chewing itself.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of misophonia sufferers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an intensive behavioral treatment intervention (BENIT) for cessation of areca nut and betel quid (ANBQ) chewing among habitual users.
results_summary: The study found that the intensive behavioral treatment intervention (IC) achieved a cessation rate of 38.6%, significantly higher than the control condition (9.1%). The results suggest that intensive cessation programs like BENIT are effective and should be expanded.
population_specificity: English-literate adults in Guam and Saipan who self-identified as ANBQ chewers with tobacco.
study_duration: Intervention outcomes were assessed at day 22.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the incidence and identify relevant risk factors for second primary cancers in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC), including the role of betel quid chewing.
results_summary: The study found that betel quid chewing was a significant risk factor for second primary cancers in HNSCC patients, with the head and neck region being the most common site for these cancers.
population_specificity: Patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the impact of implant-related complications on perceived pain, functional impairment (including chewing ability), concern, quality of life, and confidence in future implant treatment.
results_summary: Implant-related complications moderately impaired patients' perceptions of chewing ability, along with pain, concern, and quality of life, but only slightly reduced their confidence in future implant treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with dental implants recruited from five centers over 19 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the fracture resistance of endodontically treated posterior teeth restored with fiber-reinforced composites compared to traditional hybrid composites, focusing on their performance under occlusal loading from functions like chewing.
results_summary: Fiber-reinforced composites showed increased fracture resistance in endodontically treated teeth compared to traditional hybrid composites, though the included studies had moderate to high risk of bias. Limited evidence was found for bulk fill composites, and no comparisons were available for endo crowns.
population_specificity: Endodontically treated posterior teeth (in vitro studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of topical drug delivery methods, including chewing gum, for treating esophageal diseases.
results_summary: The abstract discusses the challenges of esophageal drug delivery and highlights the potential of topical approaches, including chewing gum, but does not provide specific results on efficacy or safety.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of esophageal disease treatment)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the failure rates and maximum load capacity of different CAD/CAM retainers (including Twistflex) for long-term stability in chewing applications.
results_summary: Twistflex retainers showed no failures during aging and had the highest load capacity, making them the gold standard. Among CAD/CAM retainers, Ti5 retainers were the most suitable alternative, while others had high failure rates and lower load capacities.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of small-molecule drugs (aspirin, metformin, and berberine) on dental stem cells (DSCs) and their potential applications in tissue engineering and regenerative medicine.
results_summary: The abstract summarizes that DSCs have excellent stem cell characteristics and that small-molecule drugs can enhance their biological properties, but it does not provide specific findings on chewing or its effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus is on dental stem cells and small-molecule drugs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of a 6-month instructional mastication intervention on body composition and biochemical indices in female patients with obesity.
results_summary: The mastication intervention group showed significant decreases in body mass index and biochemical indices compared to the conventional treatment group, suggesting that increased chewing may contribute to weight loss and improved glucose metabolism.
population_specificity: Female patients with obesity.
effective_dosage: Not specified (guidance on increased number of chews and chewing duration provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and outcomes of the profunda artery perforator (PAP) flap versus the anterolateral thigh (ALT) flap for tongue reconstruction after glossectomy, particularly focusing on functional outcomes like swallowing and chewing.
results_summary: The study found that both PAP and ALT flaps were safe and effective for tongue reconstruction, with similar complication rates and flap volumes. However, PAP flap recipients had significantly better swallowing function compared to ALT flap recipients, though both groups reported high-severity issues with swallowing/chewing and voice/speech.
population_specificity: 65 patients who underwent subtotal or total glossectomy reconstruction between 2016 and 2020 (46 ALT flap recipients, 19 PAP flap recipients).
study_duration: Follow-up included assessments at two time points, with flap volume measured 7 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between myasthenia gravis-like paraneoplastic neurological syndrome and lung adenocarcinoma, particularly its impact on chewing and other neuromuscular functions.
results_summary: The study found that the patient's chewing problems, along with other symptoms like limb weakness and choking cough, did not improve significantly despite treatment with intrathecal pemetrexed, neurotrophic therapy, and later cabozantinib. The findings suggest that MG-like paraneoplastic syndrome secondary to lung cancer may be resistant to standard treatments.
population_specificity: A 55-year-old female with lung adenocarcinoma presenting with neuromuscular symptoms.
study_duration: Half a year (symptoms persisted despite interventions)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of denture adhesives (powder and cream types) on masticatory performance in complete denture wearers compared to a saline control.
results_summary: All groups showed significant improvement in masticatory performance post-intervention, but no significant difference was found among the denture adhesive groups and saline. Denture adhesives were more effective in individuals with unsatisfactory intraoral conditions.
population_specificity: Complete denture wearers in Japan, excluding those with severe systemic illness, metal base dentures, or severe xerostomia.
study_duration: September 2013 to October 2016 (exact intervention duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combined orthodontic and restorative approach improves chewing, swallowing, and language function in patients with malocclusion and dental defects.
results_summary: The study found that the combined treatment improved chewing function, swallowing and language scores, and periodontal health compared to routine restoration alone, with higher patient satisfaction in the study group.
population_specificity: 112 patients with malocclusion and dentition defects admitted to Lianyungang Hospital of Traditional Chinese Medicine.
study_duration: June 2019 to June 2022 (exact intervention duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review advances in understanding the neural basis of oro-facial functions, including chewing, over the past five decades.
results_summary: The abstract highlights progress in neuroscience research related to oro-facial pain and its neural mechanisms but does not provide specific findings on chewing's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of neuroscience research).

study_goal: To investigate whether occlusal equilibration therapy (ET) and reducing the steeper angle of lateral mandibular movement could reduce chronic temporomandibular disorder (TMD) pain intensity.
results_summary: ET significantly reduced facial pain intensity (mean difference -1.54, p=0.004) and increased maximum unassisted mouth opening (mean difference 3.1 mm, p=0.02) compared to sham therapy over 6 months, with no serious adverse events reported.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic temporomandibular disorders (TMDs).
effective_dosage: Minimal invasive occlusal remodeling to achieve balanced occlusion (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the correlation between masticatory efficiency and dynamic postural balance in complete denture patients at 3 and 6 months after denture insertion.
results_summary: The study found a negative correlation between dynamic postural balance and masticatory efficiency at both 3 and 6 months, indicating that improved masticatory efficiency was associated with better postural balance. Prosthodontic rehabilitation was concluded to be important for enhancing postural balance and preventing falls in the elderly.
population_specificity: Fifty edentulous healthy patients rehabilitated with conventional complete dentures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the parallels between aging and spaceflight physiology, focusing on non-invasive treatments like transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) for conditions affecting chewing and swallowing.
results_summary: The study highlights the potential of non-invasive methods like TMS to address issues such as masticatory muscle dysfunction, swallowing biomechanics, and related pathologies, though specific efficacy data on chewing were not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on aging and spaceflight physiology).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the development and therapeutic potential of smart stimuli-responsive hydrogels for treating periodontitis, considering challenges like reduced drug residence due to chewing and other oral functions.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that chewing and saliva secretion reduce drug residence in periodontal lesions, complicating treatment, and discusses smart hydrogels as a promising solution due to their stimuli-responsive drug release capabilities.
population_specificity: Not specified (review paper, not a clinical study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) related to the feeding skills domain, including chewing, in children with pediatric feeding disorder (PFD).
results_summary: The review identified 14 PROMs, with variable methodological quality, focusing primarily on impairment (e.g., biting/chewing) and activity rather than social participation. Tools with stronger content validity and development processes scored higher.
population_specificity: Children ≥6 months with pediatric feeding disorder (PFD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if adding gum-chewing to oral carbohydrate loading reduces preoperative anxiety and affects gastric volume in patients undergoing gynecologic surgery.
results_summary: The study found that adding gum-chewing to oral carbohydrate loading significantly reduced preoperative anxiety and improved patient-rated quality of recovery after surgery, with no difference in gastric volume between groups.
population_specificity: Women undergoing elective gynecologic surgery.
effective_dosage: 400 mL of oral carbohydrate the evening before and 200-400 mL 3 hours before surgery, with gum-chewing freely during preanesthetic fasting.
study_duration: Preoperative fasting period (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether CPP-ACP added to foodstuffs (milk, chewing gums, or candies) has a remineralizing or inhibitory effect on dental demineralization.
results_summary: The study found that CPP-ACP added to milk, chewing gum, or candy has potential remineralizing activity on tooth enamel and some antibacterial effects on dental biofilm, though further clinical studies are needed to confirm clinical significance.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vivo and in situ studies included).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chewing gum could reduce preoperative anxiety in pregnant women undergoing elective cesarean section under regional anesthesia.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in preoperative anxiety levels between the gum-chewing and control groups. However, the gum-chewing group reported significantly lower pain scores during the combined spinal epidural anesthesia procedure.
population_specificity: Pregnant women undergoing elective cesarean section under regional anesthesia.
effective_dosage: Chewing xylitol gum for at least 10 minutes per hour, regardless of fasting.
study_duration: From 5 pm the day before surgery until entering the operation room.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review studies investigating the etiology of Body Focused Repetitive Behaviors (BFRB), including cheek chewing, to better understand its clinical features, incidence, and treatment.
results_summary: The study found that BFRB, including cheek chewing, is often investigated in adult populations, with high rates of comorbid psychiatric diseases and small sample sizes complicating research. Behavioral models and genetic inheritance were highlighted, along with neurocognitive and neuroimaging abnormalities.
population_specificity: Adult populations with BFRB, including cheek chewing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the connections between chewing function, salivation, and xerostomia on oral health in patients receiving long-term enteral or parenteral nutrition.
results_summary: The study found that chewing function, salivation, and xerostomia significantly impact oral health in patients on long-term nutritional support, highlighting the need for regular oral assessments by nurses to mitigate risks of oral diseases.
population_specificity: Patients on long-term enteral or parenteral nutrition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between symptom severity (including chewing) and utility values in patients with generalized myasthenia gravis (gMG), as well as the impact of efgartigimod therapy on these outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that chewing was one of the MG-ADL items with the largest improvements in the EFG + CT group, and it significantly contributed to utility values. Each unit improvement in MG-ADL (including chewing) led to a statistically significant utility increase.
population_specificity: Adult patients with generalized myasthenia gravis (gMG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the pain profile of patients during the levelling/alignment phase of orthodontic treatment, particularly focusing on pain related to chewing and occlusion.
results_summary: The study found that chewing significantly increased pain (MD = 19.2 mm on VAS) compared to baseline, with peak pain occurring on day 1 after appliance insertion. Pain decreased gradually over the first week, and analgesic use was common, peaking at 6 hours post-insertion.
population_specificity: 2277 patients (40.3% male; mean age 17.5 years) undergoing orthodontic treatment.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (pain assessment, not a supplement).
study_duration: First week after orthodontic appliance insertion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the safety and efficacy of preoperative chewing gum in adult patients undergoing elective surgery.
results_summary: Preoperative chewing gum showed no significant difference in gastric pH or fluid volume but was associated with reduced preoperative thirst, lower incidence of postoperative nausea, sore throat, hoarseness, and pain, as well as shorter recovery times and hospital stays.
population_specificity: Adult patients undergoing elective surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe plasma cell gingivitis (PCG) and its potential association with hypersensitivity to chewing gums and other oral antigens.
results_summary: The study identified PCG as an inflammatory condition linked to hypersensitivity to chewing gums and other oral antigens, with lesions unresponsive to prophylactic treatment. Diagnosis involves patient history and clinicopathologic correlation to rule out mimics.
population_specificity: Patients with plasma cell gingivitis (PCG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of khat use during pregnancy on perinatal and maternal outcomes through a meta-analysis of available studies.
results_summary: Khat use during pregnancy was significantly associated with increased odds of low birth weight, congenital anomalies, premature rupture of membranes, perinatal mortality, lower APGAR scores, maternal psychological stress, and anemia. No significant differences were found for stillbirth and preterm birth.
population_specificity: Pregnant women who used khat during pregnancy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the adverse health effects of betel quid chewing, particularly its association with oral cancer and systemic diseases.
results_summary: Betel quid chewing causes oral mucosal damage, leading to precancerous lesions like oral submucosal fibrosis and increased risk of malignancy. Patients with this habit also exhibit higher rates of systemic diseases such as metabolic syndrome and cardiovascular conditions compared to non-chewers.
population_specificity: Patients with a history of betel quid chewing, smoking, and alcohol drinking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of probiotics on halitosis (bad breath) from a time perspective, comparing short-term (≤4 weeks) and long-term (>4 weeks) outcomes.
results_summary: Probiotics significantly reduced organoleptic (OLP) scores and volatile sulfur compound (VSC) levels in the short term, with OLP scores also showing significant reduction in the long term. No significant differences were observed in secondary outcomes (tongue coating scores and plaque index).
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract (likely individuals with halitosis).
study_duration: Short term (≤4 weeks) and long term (>4 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intra-articular injection of i-PRF after arthrocentesis improves pain reduction and jaw movement more effectively than arthrocentesis alone in patients with disc displacement without reduction (DDWoR).
results_summary: The study found that the combination of arthrocentesis and i-PRF injection significantly improved pain reduction and jaw movement compared to arthrocentesis alone, with a 100% treatment success rate in the i-PRF group versus 73.7% in the control group. The improvements were statistically significant and sustained over 12 months.
population_specificity: Patients with diagnosed DDWoR, experiencing localized joint pain and limited range of motion (76 participants: 69 females, 7 males, mean age ~47 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of topical hyaluronic acid, hypochlorous acid, and flurbiprofen on postoperative morbidity and wound healing at palatal donor sites after free gingival graft surgery.
results_summary: Hyaluronic acid improved wound healing and color matching, while hypochlorous acid and flurbiprofen reduced pain but potentially hindered palatal wound healing. The use of HA was found to accelerate wound healing and reduce postoperative complications.
population_specificity: 60 patients requiring free gingival grafts.
effective_dosage: HA gel (600 mg/100 g high molecular weight hyaluronic acid), HOCl spray (170-200 ppm, pH 7.1), flurbiprofen spray (0.075 g flurbiprofen).
study_duration: 14 days of topical application, with follow-up for 28 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine and analyze the prevalence of complications post simple exodontia (CPES).
results_summary: The study identified trismus, alveolitis, pain, dehiscence, infections, and retained roots as common complications after simple exodontia, with trismus, alveolitis, and retained roots being the most prevalent. These complications were linked to surgeon experience, surgery duration, and tissue trauma.
population_specificity: Human subjects undergoing simple exodontia (excluding third molar exodontia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of two denture fabrication techniques (selective pressure impression and functional impression) on masticatory efficiency and oral health-related quality of life in patients with resorbed ridges.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in masticatory efficiency or oral health-related quality of life between the two denture fabrication techniques, suggesting both methods are similarly effective for patients with resorbed ridges.
population_specificity: 48 participants (45 completed follow-up) with resorbed ridges, mean age 62.7 ± 3.8 years.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (denture fabrication techniques, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the function and coordination of masticatory muscles between patients with two implant-supported mandibular overdentures (ISOD) and conventional complete dentures (CCD) using surface electromyography (sEMG).
results_summary: The study found that ISOD significantly increased masticatory muscle activity (masseter and temporalis) during clenching, cotton roll clenching, and chewing compared to CCD, indicating improved chewing efficiency and retention. No statistically significant difference was observed between the left and right sides, suggesting symmetrical muscle activity.
population_specificity: 15 edentulous patients (nine males and six females).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review chewing interventions within the applied behavior analysis literature to assess their effectiveness in teaching and improving chewing skills.
results_summary: The study identified a small but growing body of literature demonstrating the effectiveness of multicomponent treatment packages for improving chewing skills, suggesting the need for future research on participant characteristics, broader definitions of chewing, and multidisciplinary interventions.
population_specificity: Pediatric populations (implied by "pediatric chewing interventions").

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of food hardness (hard vs. soft diets) on behavior, cognition, and brain activation in animals and humans.
results_summary: A hard food diet improved behavioral task performance in 48% of animal studies, with some human studies showing positive associations between chewing hard food, cognition, and brain function. However, 44% of animal studies found no differential effects, and methodological variations hindered meta-analysis.
population_specificity: Animals and humans (18 animal studies, 6 human studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pathophysiology, consequences, types, and treatment methods of bruxism to enhance understanding of the condition.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that bruxism can cause various complications like headaches, tooth wear, and muscle pain, but standardized treatment approaches are lacking. It also emphasizes the need for preventive measures and targeted informational projects.
population_specificity: Patients with bruxism (both awake and sleep bruxism).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Mineral Trioxide Aggregate (MTA) and Bioceramic putty in primary molar pulpotomy for children with irreversible pulpitis.
results_summary: The study found that both MTA and Bioceramic putty were highly effective, with success rates of 95% and 100%, respectively, after one year, though Bioceramic showed slightly better outcomes. No statistically significant differences were observed between the two materials.
population_specificity: 40 healthy children aged 6-8 years with primary mandibular molars.
effective_dosage: Not specified (materials used as capping agents in pulpotomy).
study_duration: 1 year (follow-up at 1 week, 3 months, 6 months, 9 months, and 1 year).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chewing gum as part of an ERAS protocol to reduce postoperative ileus in patients undergoing urogynecological surgery.
results_summary: The study found that chewing gum is an effective component of ERAS protocols, with strong evidence supporting its use to reduce postoperative ileus in urogynecological surgery patients. It was included among other high-evidence components like fasting guidelines and multimodal analgesia.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing urogynecological surgery.

study_goal: To determine the effect of triamcinolone acetonide (TA) and saline irrigation of major salivary glands on relieving xerostomia in Sjögren's syndrome (SS) patients.
results_summary: Both TA and saline irrigation increased chewing-stimulated whole saliva flow (SWS) and citric acid-stimulated parotid flow (SPF) at 8, 16, and 24 weeks post-treatment. ESSPRI (oral dryness domain) scores were significantly lower at these time points compared to baseline, indicating relief of xerostomia.
population_specificity: 49 Sjögren's syndrome patients (14 per group after follow-up).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 1, 8, 16, and 24 weeks post-irrigation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether daily consumption of chewing tablets containing thermally inactivated [substance] over 2 weeks could address ECC (Early Childhood Caries).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results regarding the effects of the chewing tablets.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of sugar-free polyol chewing gums (xylitol, sorbitol, maltitol) on gingival inflammation.
results_summary: Xylitol gum decreased gingival scores in five out of seven studies, while sorbitol showed a small decrease compared to controls. The evidence for maltitol was limited, and overall findings were inconclusive due to study heterogeneity.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population with gingival inflammation, inferred).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compile evidence on primate self-medication modes, including chewing, to understand plant use for preventive or therapeutic purposes.
results_summary: The study identified bitter pith chewing as one of the self-medicative behaviors associated with antiparasitic, antibacterial, and anti-inflammatory properties. Plant uses were widespread across primate species, suggesting potential medicinal benefits.
population_specificity: Wild nonhuman primates (25 species across 9 families).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of systemic medications and polypharmacy on unstimulated and chewing-stimulated whole saliva flow rates in patients with xerostomia.
results_summary: The study found that certain medications, particularly antidepressants, corticosteroids, and DMARDs, negatively impacted both unstimulated and chewing-stimulated saliva flow rates, while non-opioid analgesics and sex hormones had positive or neutral effects. Polypharmacy within the same drug class exacerbated these effects.
population_specificity: 1,144 patients (85% female, mean age 59 years) with xerostomia referred to oral medicine outpatient practices in Europe and the USA.
study_duration: Data collected from January 2000 to April 2014 (cross-sectional study, no intervention duration specified)
interactions: Negative interactions noted with opioid analgesics, anticonvulsants, antidepressants, antihypertensives, benzodiazepines, corticosteroids, diuretics, DMARDs, and hormones. Positive interaction noted with non-opioid analgesics and sex hormones.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare masticatory muscle activity between people with cystic fibrosis (pwCF) and healthy controls and assess whether craniocervical dysfunction is associated with CF.
results_summary: Muscle activity during chewing showed no significant difference between pwCF and healthy controls. However, pwCF had a higher prevalence of craniocervical dysfunction (75% vs. 64%) and were 1.53 times more likely to have reduced cervical mobility.
population_specificity: 56 participants (13 children/adolescents and 15 adults per group) with cystic fibrosis and healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of chewing gum as part of an ERAS protocol to reduce postoperative ileus in patients undergoing urogynecological surgery.
results_summary: The study found that chewing gum is an effective component of ERAS protocols, with strong evidence supporting its use to reduce postoperative ileus. It was included among other high-evidence components for perioperative care.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing urogynecological surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the postoperative outcomes of minimally-invasive versus conventional envelope flaps in impacted mandibular third molar surgery, focusing on chewing and other quality-of-life factors.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in chewing, swallowing, trismus, or pain after seven days between the two flap techniques. Other quality-of-life measures, such as oral hygiene and speech discomfort, were impacted by flap choice.
population_specificity: 60 patients aged 18 or older with impacted mandibular third molars.
study_duration: Postoperative outcomes were evaluated over at least seven days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the importance of oral health in HIV-positive patients, particularly how oral lesions can impact chewing and overall quality of life.
results_summary: The study found that oral lesions in HIV-positive patients can compromise chewing, among other functions, and emphasized the need for early diagnosis and treatment to improve patient outcomes.
population_specificity: HIV-positive patients, particularly those with advanced disease (AIDS stage, <200 CD4+ T lymphocytes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the oral health effects of prolonged Pituri chewing, particularly focusing on potential adverse outcomes like lesions, while balancing cultural significance.
results_summary: The study reported a lesion on the anterior buccal mucosa from prolonged Pituri use, but broader adverse oral outcomes remain elusive. Most prior research focused on obstetric issues rather than oral health.
population_specificity: Aboriginal groups in Central Australia who chew wild tobacco (Pituri).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a wearable chewing counter could effectively change masticatory behavior (chewing frequency and meal duration) in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: The study found that using a wearable chewing counter, especially with a behavioral change algorithm (real-time feedback and target setting), significantly increased the number of chews and meal duration compared to the control group. Subjective evaluations also indicated the highest improvement in masticatory behavior for the algorithm-assisted group.
population_specificity: 235 healthy volunteers
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved monitoring and feedback, not a dosage)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the prevalence of orofacial pain and dysfunction, including chewing difficulties, in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD).
results_summary: The study found that chewing difficulties (N = 9) and other orofacial motor dysfunctions were more common in PD patients than in healthy controls, indicating significant orofacial impairment in this population.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease (PD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an early childhood educational intervention on nutrition, oral hygiene, and child stimulation could improve oral health outcomes, including chewing-related issues, in 5-6-year-old children.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly reduced molar caries (41% vs. 60%), higher toothbrush use (66% vs. 38%), and fewer self-reported chewing problems (8.5% vs. 18%) compared to the control group. No significant differences were found in dietary habits.
population_specificity: 5-6-year-old children in rural Uganda whose mothers participated in the original trial when the children were 6-8 months old.
study_duration: 6 months (initial intervention), follow-up at 5-6 years of age

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the Betel Nut Intervention Trial (BENIT) in helping Pacific Islanders quit chewing Areca catechu nut (AN) and to verify self-reported chewing status using salivary alkaloid levels.
results_summary: The study found that salivary AN alkaloid levels decreased significantly in quitters, particularly for arecoline, arecaidine, and nicotine, supporting the use of saliva bioverification to assess compliance in AN cessation programs. Chewers showed a significant decrease only in hydroxycotinine.
population_specificity: Minority Pacific Islanders in Guam and Saipan.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of oncogenic viruses in head and neck cancers, including the impact of traditional risk factors like chewing tobacco.
results_summary: The study noted a reduction in head and neck cancers linked to traditional risk factors such as chewing tobacco, with viral infections emerging as a major contributor. It highlighted the potential for viral gene-specific targets in diagnosis and prognosis.
population_specificity: Patients with head and neck cancers, particularly those associated with traditional risk factors like chewing tobacco.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the peri-implant clinicoradiographic status among betel-quid chewers (with and without tobacco) compared to non-users.
results_summary: Betel-quid chewing (with or without tobacco) was associated with significantly higher peri-implant soft-tissue inflammation and crestal bone loss compared to controls, with no significant difference between tobacco and non-tobacco chewers.
population_specificity: 90 participants (30 betel-quid chewers with tobacco, 30 without tobacco, 30 non-users).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the pharmacokinetic profiles of acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) and salicylic acid (SA) between an oral aspirin solution and a chewed aspirin tablet under fasting and fed conditions.
results_summary: The study found that the oral aspirin solution provided faster and higher plasma concentrations of ASA and SA compared to the chewed tablet, with greater exposure under both fasting and fed conditions. The oral solution showed 74% greater ASA concentration under fasting and 115% greater under fed conditions at 3 minutes.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects
effective_dosage: 300 mg of aspirin (either as a 15-mL oral solution or a single chewed tablet)
study_duration: Single administration per treatment visit, with a 10-day wash-out period between visits

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an integrated smoking cessation intervention, including nicotine chewing gum, for patients receiving opioid agonist therapy (OAT) who smoke tobacco.
results_summary: The study protocol describes a multicentre randomized controlled trial to assess smoking cessation or reduction, with primary outcomes measured at 16 weeks and sustained effects evaluated at 1 year. Secondary outcomes include changes in psychological well-being, inflammation markers, physical health, quality of life, and fatigue.
population_specificity: Daily tobacco-smoking patients receiving OAT in outpatient clinics in Bergen and Stavanger, Norway.
effective_dosage: Not specified (prescription-free nicotine replacement products, including chewing gum, were provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether postsurgical gum chewing could restore normal bowel movement in colorectal cancer patients after abdominal surgery for colon resection.
results_summary: The study found that gum chewing significantly reduced the time to first postoperative flatus and defecation compared to the control group, though only the reduction in time to first flatus remained significant after controlling for age and surgical duration. Positive correlations were observed between time to first flatus and defecation in both groups.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and older patients who underwent open abdominal surgery for colorectal resection.
effective_dosage: One piece of xylitol chewing gum for 15 minutes, 3 times daily.
study_duration: From the first day after surgery until the first flatus and defecation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of miswak (chewing sticks from Salvadora persica and Azadirachta indica) in maintaining periodontal health among adults, comparing its use to toothbrushes and as an adjunctive therapy.
results_summary: Miswak was comparable to toothbrushes in reducing plaque and gingivitis scores when used exclusively, and adjunctive use of miswak was significantly more effective in improving periodontal health. The study noted higher certainty of evidence for plaque reduction on the labial surface of anterior teeth.
population_specificity: Adults, particularly those in Western Asia and Muslim populations worldwide.

study_goal: To assess pain, discomfort, and functional impairment in children undergoing extraction of primary canine or primary canine and primary first molar as an interceptive treatment for palatally displaced permanent canines.
results_summary: Tooth extraction was associated with low levels of pain and discomfort overall, but double extractions (canine and first molar) caused significantly more pain and discomfort than single extractions. Chewing problems were reported by one-third to half of the children, but few experienced other jaw impairments.
population_specificity: Children aged 9.5-14 years with displaced permanent maxillary canines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to map the literature on oral health indicators, including chewing problems, and their impact on oral health-related quality of life in older adults receiving home health care services.
results_summary: The study found that chewing problems were common among older adults receiving home health care services, often associated with poor oral health status, including missing teeth, plaque, caries, and xerostomia. These issues negatively impacted daily activities and quality of life.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 65+ receiving home health care services.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how chewing efficiency and oral health-related quality of life (OHRQoL) in edentulous patients improved with the use of one, two, or three mandibular implants supporting complete dentures.
results_summary: Chewing efficacy significantly increased after implant loading, with the best results achieved using two implants. OHRQoL also improved significantly after implant placement.
population_specificity: Edentulous patients aged 50+ years receiving mandibular implants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on sound tolerance conditions, including terminology, definitions, assessment methods, and treatment approaches.
results_summary: The study noted inconsistencies in terminology, definitions, and methodologies for assessing and treating sound tolerance conditions, but did not provide specific findings on Chewing.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers investigated the prevalence of late effects, including oral and masticatory dysfunction, in childhood cancer survivors treated before age three.
results_summary: The study found that 26.9% of survivors experienced oral and masticatory dysfunction, with higher prevalence in those who received radiotherapy. Radiotherapy was significantly associated with dental or chewing difficulties (p = 0.001).
population_specificity: Childhood cancer survivors diagnosed before age three, treated between 1991 and 2016, with a median follow-up of 9.85 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current state of behavioral feeding interventions, including chewing, and provide suggestions for future research and clinical work.
results_summary: The abstract highlights important contributions in chewing-related studies but does not specify detailed findings about chewing's effects. It suggests future research directions and clinical considerations.
population_specificity: Not specified (general review of behavioral feeding interventions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the methodological quality and risk of bias in systematic reviews on treatments for molar-incisor hypomineralization (MIH), including non-invasive options like sugar-free chewing gum.
results_summary: The study found that sugar-free chewing gum was among the non-invasive treatments identified as potentially suitable for MIH, but the overall evidence supporting treatments was limited due to methodological quality and risk of bias in the systematic reviews.
population_specificity: Patients with molar-incisor hypomineralization (MIH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of bite force (occlusal force) in dental treatment outcomes, including its impact on restoration longevity and chewing efficiency.
results_summary: The study found that bite force varies by tooth location, age, and sex, with higher forces in the posterior region and reduced proprioception in endodontically treated teeth. Bite force influences restoration life expectancy, material selection, and implant design, suggesting tailored treatment planning for patients with elevated bite forces.
population_specificity: Dental patients, with noted variations by sex and age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical masticatory performance of implant-supported restorations, assess occlusal force changes, and identify contributing factors of implant design and components.
results_summary: Implant-supported restorations significantly improved bite force and chewing efficiency compared to conventional dentures. Smaller implant sizes and flexible attachment designs were found to enhance stability and retention, especially in cases of alveolar bone atrophy.
population_specificity: Patients with edentulous restoration supported by implants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if there is a temporal association between invasive dental procedures (and by extension, daily activities like chewing) and subsequent infective endocarditis, particularly in high-risk individuals.
results_summary: The study found no direct evidence linking chewing to infective endocarditis but noted that oral bacteria-related infective endocarditis may more likely result from daily activities like chewing, especially in those with poor oral hygiene. Data limitations, however, weakened the certainty of any conclusions.
population_specificity: Individuals admitted to hospital with infective endocarditis in the English NHS between 2010 and 2016.
study_duration: Observational study with data spanning 6 years (2010–2016).

study_goal: To explore the effects of different repair and reconstruction methods combined with psychological intervention on the quality of life and negative emotion of patients with oral cancer.
results_summary: Psychological intervention improved mental state and quality of life in oral cancer patients, with groups receiving it (A and B) showing lower clinical symptom and negative emotion scores compared to the control group (C). The effect of psychological intervention was similar across different repair methods.
population_specificity: 180 patients with oral cancer treated between January 2018 and January 2020.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess masseter stiffness in patients with masticatory muscle disorders and evaluate the efficacy of manual therapy and stabilization occlusal splint in treating these disorders.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in masseter stiffness (by 4.21 kPa) and pain (median scores dropped from 5-8 to 0-1), along with improvements in patient-reported outcomes like anxiety, sleep quality, and life satisfaction.
population_specificity: 35 patients with masticatory muscle disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify modifiable factors contributing to hospital-acquired malnutrition, including chewing difficulties.
results_summary: Chewing difficulties were identified as one of the frequently reported barriers to optimal nutrition among hospital inpatients, contributing to nutritional deterioration. The study did not specifically evaluate the efficacy of interventions to address chewing difficulties.
population_specificity: Adult hospital inpatients, both previously well-nourished and nutritionally compromised.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether physiotherapeutic exercises for the masticatory muscles (MaMuT) improve chewing efficiency and bite force in people with dementia.
results_summary: The MaMuT improved masticatory performance across all cognitive states, with increased bite force in two experimental groups and improved chewing efficiency in all experimental groups. However, effects diminished without continued training, with varying degrees of sustained improvement based on cognitive severity.
population_specificity: People with dementia (stratified by MMSE scores: group 1-28-30, group 2-25-27, group 3-18-24).
effective_dosage: Part 1: Three physiotherapeutic treatments plus daily home exercises; Part 2: Daily home exercises only.
study_duration: Not explicitly stated (intervention phase and follow-up implied but not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of chewing ability in the nutritional management of COVID-19 patients, particularly in relation to respiratory autonomy and the choice of feeding routes.
results_summary: The study found that spontaneous oral feeding, considering chewing ability and swallowing, is strongly indicated for non-mechanically ventilated COVID-19 patients. If oral feeding is insufficient or not feasible, enteral or parenteral nutrition is recommended, with enteral nutrition preferred for its lower risk of complications.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients, particularly those not mechanically ventilated or with non-invasive ventilation (NIV).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the pathogenesis of bilateral tonsillar squamous cell carcinoma (biTSCC) in a patient with a history of chewing tobacco.
results_summary: The study identified synchronous biTSCC with differing tumor pathology and karyotype, supporting the multiple HPV infections hypothesis. No direct effects of chewing tobacco on tumor development were conclusively established.
population_specificity: A 49-year-old male with a remote history of chewing tobacco.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the factors influencing successful dental implant integration for chewing functionality and esthetics, focusing on surface characteristics and gingival attachment.
results_summary: The study found that implant surface microtopography and chemistry enhance osseointegration, while strong gingival attachment prevents bacterial infiltration, contributing to clinical success. The biomechanics of the implant-abutment connection also play a critical role.
population_specificity: Not specified (implied general population requiring dental implants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) on postoperative pain, wound healing, and patient-reported outcomes after free gingival graft (FGG) harvesting.
results_summary: PBMT significantly reduced postoperative pain, decreased rescue medication use, improved wound closure, and enhanced patient satisfaction compared to placebo, particularly within the first 48 hours. No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: 44 patients requiring free gingival graft (FGG) procedures.
effective_dosage: PBMT applied immediately after surgery, and at 24 and 48 hours post-surgery.
study_duration: 72 hours (with follow-up at 7 days for wound closure).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify prognostic factors for patient satisfaction and evaluate the effectiveness and safety of a single intra-articular injection of HANOX-M-XL in patients with TMJ-OA.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in pain while chewing and improved mandibular mobility, with 94% of patients rating the treatment as highly effective or effective. Tolerability was good in all but one patient, and no safety concerns were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with TMJ-OA not relieved by analgesics, NSAIDs, or orthotics, with radiological evidence of TMJ-OA (mean age 55.3 years, mean disease duration 98 months).
effective_dosage: Single intra-articular injection of 1 ml HANOX-M-XL.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the therapeutic actions of Chios mastiha and discuss its potential future medical applications, particularly in chewing gum form.
results_summary: The study highlights Chios mastiha's anti-inflammatory and anti-oxidative properties, with evidence supporting its beneficial effects, including approval for mild dyspeptic disorders and skin inflammations. Its primary modern use is in natural chewing gum production.
population_specificity: Not specified (general therapeutic applications discussed).
