study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of non-surgical interventions (botulinum toxin, functional masticatory training, neuromuscular electrostimulation) for treating masticatory muscle spasticity in cerebral palsy patients.
results_summary: The study found very low certainty evidence: (i) no difference between botulinum toxin and placebo in chewing strength and efficiency, (ii) improved masticatory function with functional training versus conventional exercises, and (iii) improved outcomes with strengthening exercises plus neuromuscular electrostimulation versus placebo.
population_specificity: Patients with cerebral palsy experiencing masticatory muscle spasticity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the treatment of cachexia in head and neck cancer (HNC) patients, focusing on interventions that address functional changes like chewing.
results_summary: The study found that nutritional, pharmacologic, therapeutic exercise, and multimodal interventions could help manage cachexia in HNC patients, potentially improving survival and quality of life. Chewing was indirectly addressed as part of broader functional impairments.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer (HNC) patients with cachexia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the expanded concept of oral care, including chewing, and its broader health implications beyond dental hygiene.
results_summary: The study found that oral care, including chewing, is linked to the prevention and management of various diseases (e.g., pneumonia, diabetes, cardiovascular diseases) and supports dignity in terminal care. It also noted medical and economic benefits like reduced hospitalization duration and treatment costs.
population_specificity: General population, with implications for elderly, terminally ill, and disaster-affected individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of gum chewing in reducing time to first hunger after major abdominal surgery.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of 4 randomized controlled trials found that gum chewing reduced time to first hunger by 21.2 hours among patients who had bowel surgery. The study also noted that gum chewing had level IA evidence supporting its efficacy for postoperative appetite improvement.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing major abdominal surgery, including esophageal, gastric, small bowel, colon, rectal, hepatobiliary, and pancreatic surgeries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the incidence and risk factors for non-adaptation to conventional mandibular complete dentures (CMCDs) in edentulous patients.
results_summary: After 3 months, 38.0% of patients showed non-adaptation to CMCDs, with factors like absence of previous denture experience, ulcerations, and reduced mandibular ridges hindering adaptation. By 6 months, non-adaptation decreased to 14.1%, with ulcerative lesions and non-regular denture wear remaining as significant risk factors.
population_specificity: 108 edentulous patients rehabilitated with complete dentures.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (denture use, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and feasibility of a new injection paradigm (FollowTheSutures) using onabotulinimtoxin A for treating chronic migraine by targeting cranial sutures.
results_summary: The procedure was well tolerated with only one treatment-related adverse event (reduced power of chewing for some weeks). Patients improved on most efficacy parameters after the injections, with little to no effect on glabellar or forehead lines.
population_specificity: 19 women with chronic migraine.
effective_dosage: 90 units of onabotulinimtoxin A (Botox®) injected in 18 sites over the cranial sutures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of conservative interventions on self-reported and physical measures of bite function in individuals with temporomandibular disorder (TMD).
results_summary: The review found that manual therapy, needling, oral splinting, exercise, and photobiomodulation may improve bite function in TMD, though evidence quality ranged from moderate to very low. Patient education showed no improvement in bite function.
population_specificity: Individuals diagnosed with temporomandibular disorder (TMD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the analgesic effects of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) and paracetamol-caffeine on orthodontic pain induced by elastomeric separators, as well as their impact on oral health-related quality of life (OHRQoL).
results_summary: LLLT and paracetamol-caffeine both reduced orthodontic pain compared to placebo, with LLLT showing slightly better efficacy. However, neither treatment improved overall OHRQoL, which worsened during the study period.
population_specificity: 54 patients (22 male, 32 female; mean age 21.68 ± 2.77 years) undergoing orthodontic treatment with elastomeric separators.
effective_dosage: Paracetamol-caffeine tablets (3 times daily for the first couple of days, then as needed); LLLT (808 nm, 350 mW, 3.5 J/point, single dose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the available literature on drivers and interventions for cessation of areca nut (AN) chewing habit and highlight research gaps.
results_summary: The study found socio-cultural factors, addictive nature, and withdrawal symptoms as barriers to quitting AN, while knowledge of health risks, absence of concurrent alcohol or smoking, and family pressure were associated with cessation likelihood. Interventions were mostly behavioral, with one study using antidepressants.
population_specificity: Individuals with areca nut chewing habits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze unusual clinical manifestations, including oral automatisms like chewing, in patients with Panayiotopoulos syndrome.
results_summary: Two children (4.8%) exhibited oral automatisms such as chewing, but the study primarily focused on broader electroclinical features and outcomes, not specifically chewing efficacy or safety.
population_specificity: 44 patients with Panayiotopoulos syndrome presenting with unusual seizure semiology, seen at eight Argentine centers.
study_duration: Retrospective study spanning April 2000 to April 2019 (no specific intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the bioavailability of a vitamin D3 orally disintegrating film (ODF) that dissolves without chewing to a marketed oral vitamin D3 solution.
results_summary: The study found that the ODF formulation had a bioavailability slightly higher than the oral solution, with very similar pharmacokinetic profiles across treatments. No significant differences in bioavailability were observed under fed conditions.
population_specificity: Healthy adult subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of GM-CSF mouthwash versus Salt and Soda mouthwash in preventing and treating radiation therapy-induced oral mucositis, including its impact on chewing.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in chewing outcomes among the three treatment groups (GM-CSF, Salt and Soda, or a combination) during and after radiation therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with head and neck cancer undergoing radiation therapy.
study_duration: Duration of radiation therapy (specific length not mentioned)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of chewing tobacco as a harm reduction alternative for smoking cessation.
results_summary: The study found inconclusive results regarding the effectiveness of chewing tobacco for quitting smoking, with evidence of continued use and additional health risks not present in traditional tobacco smoking. Public health efforts should focus on safer alternatives like nicotine replacement therapy.
population_specificity: Not specified (general substance abuse/tobacco users).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and characterize the validation of Patient-Reported Outcomes (PROs) related to chewing and other functional outcomes in head and neck oncology patients.
results_summary: The study reviewed three PROs with strong reliability and validity, but noted limited patient input in development, particularly for chewing and speech domains.
population_specificity: Head and neck oncology patients (≥ 18 years), including those with squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) and those receiving radiation or laryngectomy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of chewing mint gum versus virtual reality in reducing childbirth pain and anxiety.
results_summary: The study found that chewing mint gum significantly reduced pain and anxiety scores immediately and 30 minutes after the intervention during the first stage of childbirth, with no significant differences in pre-intervention scores among groups.
population_specificity: 93 mothers undergoing natural childbirth at Allameh Bohlool Gonabadi and Sajjadieh Torbate Jam Hospitals in 2018-2019.
effective_dosage: Chewing mint gum for 20 minutes at 4-5 cm and 7-8 cm cervical dilatations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effectiveness of clear aligner treatment (CAT) for malocclusions, including its impact on chewing comfort.
results_summary: CAT was found to be more comfortable and associated with a reduced impact on eating and chewing compared to fixed appliances, though results on pain were unclear. It was effective for mild to moderate malocclusions but inferior for severe cases.
population_specificity: Patients with mild to moderate malocclusions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dental/skeletal malocclusion and orthodontic treatment on chewing and jaw function parameters (MOBF, EMG, jaw kinematics, and chewing efficiency) in healthy children.
results_summary: Children with malocclusions showed lower chewing efficiency, MOBF, and EMG activity compared to controls, with jaw kinematics affected in unilateral posterior crossbite cases. Orthodontic treatment's impact on restoring normal jaw function had low to moderate evidence.
population_specificity: Healthy children with dental/skeletal malocclusions (primary, mixed, and permanent dentition stages).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between periodontitis stages and masticatory function, quality of life, and periodontal characteristics.
results_summary: Stage IV periodontitis was linked to greater oral-health-related quality of life impairment, reduced food intake due to chewing difficulties, and advanced periodontal breakdown compared to earlier stages. Quantitative masticatory dysfunction was associated with tooth loss, hypermobile teeth, and periodontal severity.
population_specificity: 214 subjects with periodontitis seeking oral care in a hospital setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare patient satisfaction, chewing comfort, and wear characteristics between Locator and CM LOC attachment systems for implant-supported overdentures.
results_summary: Patient satisfaction improved when switching from Locator to CM LOC, while chewing comfort improved when switching from CM LOC to Locator. Plaque accumulation was higher on PMMA than PEKK surfaces, and wear levels varied between attachment systems.
population_specificity: Seventeen edentulous patients with 53 implants.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (attachment systems, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the treatment efficacy of botulinum-A (BTX-A) for nocturnal bruxism, focusing on pain relief and reduction in bruxism events.
results_summary: BTX-A significantly improved pain at rest and reduced the number of bruxism events, but showed only slight improvement in pain during chewing. The results suggest BTX-A is effective for bruxism, though long-term effects like recurrence remain unclear.
population_specificity: 148 participants with nocturnal bruxism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of Oro-T mouthwash compared to normal saline in reducing oral mucositis symptoms, including difficulty in chewing, in cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy and/or chemotherapy.
results_summary: Oro-T mouthwash significantly delayed the onset and reduced the severity of oral mucositis symptoms, including difficulty in chewing, compared to normal saline, with no reported adverse effects leading to discontinuation. Patient-reported outcomes and clinical assessments showed improved quality of life.
population_specificity: Cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy and/or chemotherapy who developed oral mucositis.
effective_dosage: 10 ml of Oro-T mouthwash used for 1 minute, 4 times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of siwak (chewing stick) on periodontal health, including its clinical effectiveness and potential adverse effects.
results_summary: Siwak was effective at removing dental plaque and improving periodontal health over time, but its effect on subgingival microbiota was inconclusive. Gingival recession and clinical attachment loss were more commonly reported in siwak users, likely due to variations in cleaning methods.
population_specificity: Not specified (global Muslim communities using siwak).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of a school-based caries prevention program using xylitol-containing chewing gum in reducing dental plaque and caries increment in children.
results_summary: The study protocol outlines a triple-blind randomized controlled trial to evaluate the effects of xylitol chewing gum on caries prevalence, bleeding on probing, and plaque pH, but results are not yet available as the study has not commenced due to the COVID-19 pandemic.
population_specificity: Schoolchildren aged 5-14 years living in Zanskar Valley, Ladakh, India.
effective_dosage: 6 pellets per day (2 in the morning, 2 after midday meal, 2 in the afternoon), each chewed for 5 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare masticatory performance between conventional balanced occlusion (CBO) and lingualised balanced occlusion (LBO) in complete denture wearers and assess oral health self-perception using the GOHAI questionnaire.
results_summary: Masticatory performance was similar between CBO and LBO, improved with more chewing cycles, and oral health self-perception increased after the second evaluation session. The adaptive period was significant for improvements in self-perception.
population_specificity: 30 participants (14 males, 16 females; average age 65.8 years) wearing conventional complete dentures.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (natural test food: almonds chewed for 30 cycles, 40 cycles, or until ready to swallow).
study_duration: Two sessions (timing not specified beyond adaptive period).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of oral exercise in improving masticatory function in individuals aged 18 years and older.
results_summary: The meta-analysis showed that oral exercise significantly improved mean bite force (MD, 41.2; 95% CI, 11.6-70.7). The study included 18 trials, indicating a positive effect on masticatory performance.
population_specificity: Individuals aged ≥18 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to present an unusual case of aggressive primary malignancy in the mandibular anterior region associated with chronic tobacco chewing.
results_summary: The study found that chronic tobacco chewing was associated with an unusual case of aggressive primary malignancy in the mandibular anterior region, highlighting the need for comprehensive imaging to rule out primary tumors elsewhere.
population_specificity: 65-year-old male patient with chronic tobacco chewing history.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare masticatory function using a two-colour chewing-gum test before and after treatment for masticatory muscle-related temporomandibular disorder (TMD).
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in chewing function before and after treatment in the experimental group, nor when compared to the control group. The two-colour chewing-gum test was not sensitive for detecting changes in masticatory performance when impairment was not severe.
population_specificity: 21 patients with masticatory muscle-related TMD and 21 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether different presentations of denture adhesives (cream, powder, or strips) affect the masticatory function of complete denture wearers.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in masticatory performance or occlusal force between cream and powder or cream and strip denture adhesives, except for resorbed ridges where cream performed better than strips. The certainty of evidence was very low for all outcomes.
population_specificity: Complete denture wearers, including those with resorbed ridges.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify protein biomarkers for early detection and treatment of oral squamous cell cancers (OSCC) associated with chewing tobacco.
results_summary: The review identified 112 relevant studies focusing on proteomics techniques for biomarker discovery in OSCC, suggesting potential for early detection and personalized treatment, though most markers require further validation.
population_specificity: Human studies on patients with oral squamous cell cancers, particularly those associated with chewing tobacco.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the patterns and influencing factors of dental pain in fixed orthodontic patients within seven days after initial wearing of straight arch aligners and analyze the effect of chewing gum as a psychological intervention on dental pain.
results_summary: The study found that all but 3 of the 89 patients experienced some degree of dental pain at different time points, but the abstract does not clearly specify the comparative effectiveness of chewing gum as a psychological intervention.
population_specificity: 89 patients with malocclusion visiting the Department of Orthodontics of a hospital.

study_goal: To determine the efficacy of parent-implemented interventions, specifically functional feeding training, on improving chewing function in young children with cerebral palsy in low-middle income countries.
results_summary: Parent-implemented functional feeding training had a large significant effect on chewing function compared to parent-implemented oral motor exercises. The study found that interventions with active parent implementation were effective in improving chewing function in young children with CP.
population_specificity: Young children (<60 months of age) with cerebral palsy in low-middle income countries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of xylitol consumption (via chewing gum or candies) on dental plaque accumulation.
results_summary: Xylitol chewing gum reduced plaque accumulation in 13 out of 14 studies, outperforming sorbitol gum and gum base/no gum in several comparisons, while xylitol candies showed no plaque-reducing effects.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects in prospective randomized controlled clinical trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the differences between milled and 3D-printed complete removable dental prostheses (CRDPs) in terms of patient satisfaction, oral health-related quality of life, and clinical outcomes.
results_summary: The study found no differences in patient satisfaction, oral health-related quality of life, or clinical outcomes between milled and 3D-printed CRDPs, but 3D-printed CRDPs required more maintenance visits, adjustment time, and costs. Patients were willing to pay more for milled CRDPs.
population_specificity: Fifteen edentulous patients (10 men, 5 women; average age 66.7 years).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (prosthetic devices, not a supplement).
study_duration: 6 weeks per intervention (12 weeks total with crossover).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the extent, range, and nature of evidence for oral sensorimotor interventions for paediatric chewing dysfunction to inform future research and clinical guidelines.
results_summary: The review found preliminary evidence for the effectiveness of sensorimotor interventions in specific populations, particularly children with cerebral palsy, though most studies lacked controlled designs and used varied outcome measures. The interventions were multi-component, but further trials are needed to strengthen the evidence base.
population_specificity: Paediatric populations, primarily children with cerebral palsy (53% of included studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential drug-khat interactions, focusing on pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and pharmacogenetics of khat chewing.
results_summary: The study found that khat chewing can lead to clinically significant drug interactions, primarily affecting absorption and cytochrome P450 enzyme-mediated metabolism, with outcomes dependent on genotype.
population_specificity: Individuals who chew khat, particularly those on medications.
interactions: Drug-khat interactions at pharmacokinetic levels, particularly absorption and cytochrome P450 enzyme-mediated metabolism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) on pain intensity and chewing performance in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) patients with myogenic temporomandibular disorder (TMD).
results_summary: Group L (LLLT intervention) showed the lowest pain intensity (VAS scores of 5 and 6) and best chewing performance (GMD values of 6283.7 ± 257.2 µm and 6382.7 ± 303.7 µm) at T1 and T2, indicating LLLT effectively reduced pain and improved chewing for one month.
population_specificity: SLE patients with myogenic TMD (n=91).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between oral health characteristics, including chewing ability, and frailty status in older adults.
results_summary: The study found significant associations between frailty status and chewing ability, along with other oral health factors like number of teeth and prosthetic characteristics. Variability in findings was noted due to differences in study design and population characteristics.
population_specificity: Adults aged 50 years or older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of xylitol-containing chewing gum compared to other prevention strategies or placebo in reducing carious lesions in children.
results_summary: The study found very low scientific evidence supporting the effectiveness of xylitol gum for caries prevention in children, with conflicting results (preventive fraction ranging from -0.31 to 0.57). The authors concluded that insufficient evidence exists to support its use.
population_specificity: Children

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize reports on oral cavity cancer patients who do not smoke or drink alcohol (NSND), focusing on their characteristics and outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that NSND oral cavity cancer patients were mostly elderly females with tumors in the tongue and gingivobuccal mucosa, often diagnosed at early stages with PD-L1 overexpression and high tumor-infiltrating lymphocytes. Treatment response and prognosis were similar to smoking/drinking patients.
population_specificity: Nonsmoking, nondrinking (NSND) oral cavity cancer patients, predominantly elderly females.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a minimal-invasive envelope flap (MIEF) reduces postoperative consequences (pain, swelling, mouth opening limitation) and improves quality of life compared to a conventional envelope flap (CEF) after surgical removal of impacted mandibular third molars.
results_summary: The MIEF group showed significantly lower pain (especially during chewing), swelling, and mouth opening limitation compared to the CEF group, along with better postoperative quality-of-life scores. The differences were statistically significant for most outcomes, though pain reduction was not significant on days 6 and 7.
population_specificity: Adult patients with bilateral, symmetrically impacted mandibular third molars (mean age 22 ± 12.9 years, 35% females).
study_duration: Postoperative outcomes were assessed daily up to the seventh day.

study_goal: The researchers were examining unintentional weight loss in older adults and potential contributing factors, including chewing or swallowing disabilities.
results_summary: The abstract suggests dietary modifications should consider chewing or swallowing disabilities, but no specific results about chewing's effects are provided.
population_specificity: People older than 65 years experiencing unintentional weight loss.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a 12-week oral frailty measures program, including masticatory training, could effectively alleviate oral frailty in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant improvements in articulatory oral motor skill for /ta/ and tongue pressure, while no improvements were observed in the control group. The program effectively alleviated oral frailty, though its impact on preventing physical frailty and improving nutritional status requires further study.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals (mean age ~78 years) with at least 3 of 6 oral frailty criteria, including decreased chewing ability.
effective_dosage: Not specified (program included preparatory oral exercises, mouth-opening training, tongue pressure training, prosodic training, and masticatory training).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare patient-reported outcomes and experiences among three dental implant placement techniques (conventional freehand, dynamic, and static computer-aided surgery) regarding chewing difficulty and other postoperative effects.
results_summary: Patients reported significant differences in chewing difficulty expectations, duration of pain, speaking limitations, and routine activity impact among the groups, but no difference in pain magnitude, swelling, or painkiller use. Most participants found short-term functional limitations acceptable, and 89% were satisfied with the procedure.
population_specificity: 90 patients (88 completed) undergoing dental implant placement.
study_duration: Postoperative assessments at 1 week and 2 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compile regulatory information, physicochemical properties, toxicity profiles, and clinical applications of eugenol, including its use in chewing gums.
results_summary: The abstract highlights eugenol's broad bioactive properties (antioxidant, antimicrobial, etc.) and its applications in dental care, food (including chewing gums), and pharmaceuticals, but does not specify results related to chewing efficacy or safety.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential therapeutic effects of Boswellia serrata gum (via chewing) against COVID-19 and associated conditions, focusing on its safety, bioavailability, and mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study found that Boswellia serrata gum, when chewed, may improve buccal/oral hygiene and enhance bioavailability, offering antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and immunomodulatory benefits. It suggested potential efficacy in mild to moderate COVID-19 symptoms but noted the need for more clinical data.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals and those with mild to moderate COVID-19 symptoms (implied but not explicitly stated).
effective_dosage: Small to moderate doses (specific amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the long-term masticatory performance and maximum occlusal force between immediate loading and conventional loading of two-implant overdentures retained by magnetic attachments in elderly patients.
results_summary: No significant differences in masticatory performance or maximum occlusal force were observed between immediate and conventional loading groups over 5 years, though immediate loading showed a significant improvement in masticatory performance at 3 years. Maximum occlusal force correlated significantly with masticatory performance at 5 years.
population_specificity: 19 edentulous elderly patients (10 in immediate loading group, 9 in conventional loading group).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (implant loading protocols: immediate vs. 3-month delayed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the relationship between chewing areca nuts, genetic factors, and immune system changes in the context of oral submucous fibrosis (OSF).
results_summary: The study suggests that chewing areca nuts is linked to immune microenvironment changes in OSF, involving various immune cells and their released substances, but does not quantify efficacy.
population_specificity: Individuals with or at risk of oral submucous fibrosis (OSF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the diagnostic challenges posed by the rare joint appearance of oral submucous fibrosis (OSF) and lichenoid reaction features in patients who habitually chew quid.
results_summary: The study found that OSF, associated with quid chewing, leads to significant morbidity, including leathery and thickened mucosa with fibrous bands. The presence of lichenoid changes overlying submucous hyalinization in the right clinical and demographic setting should raise suspicion of OSF and prompt cessation of quid chewing.
population_specificity: Populations of the Indian subcontinent and Southeast Asia with habitual quid-chewing habits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an overview of the current status and future direction of cancer care in Sri Lanka, including preventive strategies related to chewing betel.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the need for preventive strategies to reduce chewing betel as part of broader cancer prevention efforts, but does not provide specific results on its effects.
population_specificity: General population of Sri Lanka, with a focus on cancer patients and at-risk individuals.

study_goal: To evaluate how changes in oral health and chewing efficiency affect oral-health-related quality of life (OHRQoL) in nursing-home residents over six months.
results_summary: A decline in oral health and chewing efficiency negatively impacted OHRQoL, with functional occluding pairs and dental/denture-related treatment needs being key factors.
population_specificity: Nursing-home residents (mean age 82.0 years, 77.2% women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify effective interventions for managing trismus (reduced mouth opening) in head and neck cancer patients, including chewing exercises.
results_summary: The study found no significant benefit of chewing exercises alone or with jaw mobilization devices compared to no exercise. However, chewing exercises combined with low-level laser therapy or low-intensity ultrasound showed superior results in mouth opening measurements. Follow-up reminders also improved adherence and outcomes.
population_specificity: Head and neck cancer patients with trismus (685 participants across 11 RCTs).
study_duration: Varied by study (not specified in abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of implant-supported overdentures (IODs) compared to conventional dentures (CDs) in improving oral health-related quality of life (OHRQoL) and chewing efficacy.
results_summary: The study found that IODs were frequently suggested as a cost-efficient alternative to CDs, with improvements in OHRQoL and chewing efficacy, but the comparability of economic evaluations was limited due to varied outcome measures. The additional health benefits of IODs relative to their higher costs remain unclear.
population_specificity: Patients requiring dentures (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the relationship between early predictor factors (socioeconomic, dietary, oral hygiene practices, and dental care access) and dental caries (including chewing difficulties) among 4-year-old French children.
results_summary: The study found a prevalence of early childhood caries (ECC) and severe ECC (S-ECC) at 15.8% and 5.9%, respectively, with sweet intake, low maternal education, lack of fluoride toothpaste use, and irregular dental visits identified as key risk factors. These factors negatively impacted oral health, including chewing difficulties.
population_specificity: 4-year-old children from public nursery schools in Moselle, north-eastern France (n=425).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a transdiagnostic CBT approach for treating misophonia symptoms, particularly triggered by sounds like chewing, in youth aged 8-16.
results_summary: Preliminary results from a pilot trial showed modest improvements in misophonia symptoms based on evaluator-rated scales, but the study lacked standardized assessment tools and formal diagnostic criteria.
population_specificity: Youth aged 8-16 with misophonia and their families.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the prevalence and determinants of alcohol use, including the association with khat chewing, among people with HIV/AIDS in Ethiopia.
results_summary: Khat chewing was identified as a statistically significant determinant of hazardous alcohol use among HIV patients, with an odds ratio of 3.53. The study highlights comorbid substance use (khat and cigarette) as increasing the risk of alcohol consumption in this population.
population_specificity: People with HIV/AIDS in Ethiopia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize ethnomedicinal uses, phytochemistry, biological activity, and scientific validation of chewing sticks in Namibia, while identifying research gaps.
results_summary: The study identified 41 plant species used as chewing sticks in Namibia, with some species also used for gargling and mouthwash. It revealed a significant relationship between plant family and scientific validation, noting that many species require further pharmacological and phytochemical investigation.
population_specificity: Rural communities in Namibia, particularly the Ovahimba ethnic group in the Kunene region.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify dental plaque control strategies, including sugarless chewing gum, that improve plaque indices in elderly people.
results_summary: Sugarless chewing gum showed promising results in improving dental plaque indices, but the effects were not statistically significant compared to control groups and were not long-lasting.
population_specificity: Elderly people aged 60 years and older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare short-term postsurgical symptoms after inserting one or two implants for mandibular overdenture retention to determine if the single-implant approach resulted in fewer postoperative symptoms.
results_summary: Both single and double implants resulted in mild, self-limited postoperative symptoms with progressive improvement over 21 days, showing no significant difference between the two approaches. Clinical predictors did not significantly affect symptom levels.
population_specificity: Patients receiving new complete dentures with mandibular overdentures.
effective_dosage: Not specified (implants inserted in midline or lateral incisor-canine area bilaterally).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify demographic, clinical, and biochemical factors associated with pica behaviors, particularly in blood donors, to improve clinical diagnosis and treatment.
results_summary: Pica was present in 2.2% of blood donors, with lower ferritin, non-Asian race, higher red cell distribution width, younger age, and restless legs syndrome independently associated with pica. Iron-deficient males and females were equally susceptible, and pica also occurred in donors with normal ferritin levels, indicating non-iron-related factors.
population_specificity: Racially diverse blood donors (n=11,418).
effective_dosage: Not specified (pica defined as consuming at least 8 oz of ice daily and/or non-ice substances regardless of amount/frequency).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficiency of chewing gum in reducing postoperative ileus (POI) and improving gastrointestinal (GI) function recovery within enhanced recovery programmes (ERP) after colorectal surgery.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that chewing gum had no significant effect on the occurrence of POI, time to first flatus, or time to first bowel movement, indicating it was not effective for GI function recovery in ERP.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing colorectal surgery within enhanced recovery programmes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pathogenesis, diagnosis, and treatment strategies of oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF), particularly focusing on its association with areca nut chewing.
results_summary: The study highlights that areca nut chewing is a significant risk factor for OSMF, a potentially malignant disorder, but does not provide conclusive findings on its pathogenesis or treatment efficacy.
population_specificity: Individuals with or at risk of oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a piezoelectric device on hemorrhage control during surgery and its impact on patients' quality of life, including chewing function, after endodontic microsurgery.
results_summary: The piezo group showed significantly less swelling and pain in the first few days post-surgery, required fewer analgesics, and achieved better hemorrhage control compared to the control group. Chewing function was assessed as part of the quality-of-life evaluation, but specific results for chewing alone were not detailed.
population_specificity: 40 patients undergoing endodontic microsurgery, divided into piezo (n=20) and control (n=20) groups.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical intervention, not a supplement).
study_duration: Quality of life was evaluated daily for 1 week post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the nutritional, microbiological, and cost properties of different texture-modified diets (TMDs) for patients with dysphagia and/or chewing difficulties.
results_summary: The study found that concentrated nutrient-dense commercial food products, especially those prepared with the MixxPro® automatic food mixer, provided higher caloric intake and faster, safer preparation compared to in-home pureed food. No microorganisms were detected, and patient compliance and appetite were generally high across all TMD types.
population_specificity: Elderly residents (≥65 years) in geriatric nursing homes with stable clinical conditions, estimated survival >1 month, and sufficient cognitive capacity.
effective_dosage: Not specified (portion sizes varied by TMD type).
study_duration: Not specified (observational study without explicit intervention duration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare patient satisfaction and masticatory performance between mandibular implant overdentures retained with zirconia bars versus cobalt chromium bars.
results_summary: Zirconia bars showed higher patient satisfaction in appearance, hygiene, and overall experience, but no significant difference in chewing performance was found between the two types of bars.
population_specificity: Twenty completely edentulous patients.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (dental prosthetics, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of chewing fennel seeds on salivary pH and its potential as an anti-cariogenic agent.
results_summary: Chewing fennel seeds significantly increased salivary pH immediately after consumption, followed by a gradual decrease over 30 minutes, with all changes being statistically significant. The study concluded that fennel seeds could serve as an effective anti-cariogenic agent by altering salivary pH.
population_specificity: 30 voluntary individuals from the Department of Public Health Dentistry, Sri Ramachandra University, Chennai.
study_duration: Measurements taken at baseline, immediately after chewing (0 min), and at 5, 10, 15, and 30 minutes post-chewing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze seizure characteristics, EEG patterns, treatment, and outcomes in patients with focal epilepsy presenting with affective symptoms, including chewing movements.
results_summary: The study found that 2/18 patients exhibited chewing or swallowing movements at the onset of affective seizures, alongside other symptoms like speech arrest and autonomic manifestations. The seizures were associated with typical EEG features of idiopathic focal epilepsies of childhood.
population_specificity: 18 patients with self-limited epilepsy and affective symptoms, seen at eight Argentinian centers between 2000 and 2018.
study_duration: Retrospective study spanning 18 years (April 2000 to April 2018).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a polysaccharide-containing pastille could increase salivary flow rate and alleviate dry mouth symptoms in individuals with xerostomia.
results_summary: The pastille significantly increased salivary flow rate and reduced dry mouth symptoms compared to the control product, with gum arabic detected in saliva for up to 10 minutes after use. No difference in saliva surface tension was observed between the pastille and control.
population_specificity: Subjects with xerostomia (both aged and younger individuals).
effective_dosage: Not specified (pastille used once per testing day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of chondroitin sulfate, as part of sugar-based biopolymers, for use in cancer imaging and therapy through nano-formulations.
results_summary: The study highlighted chondroitin sulfate as a promising biocompatible nanoparticle for targeted drug delivery and imaging in cancer treatment, though clinical optimization is still needed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general application in cancer therapy)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of glycosylation enzymes, including those linked to chondroitin sulfate synthesis, in prostate cancer and their regulation by androgen receptor signaling.
results_summary: The study identified chondroitin sulfate as one of the cancer-associated glycans linked to androgen-controlled glycosylation enzymes, suggesting its potential role in prostate cancer progression, but did not directly assess its effects.
population_specificity: Prostate cancer cells and tissue

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pathogenesis, diagnosis, and treatment of MPS IVA, focusing on the role of chondroitin-6-sulfate accumulation in skeletal dysplasia.
results_summary: The study describes how chondroitin-6-sulfate accumulation disrupts cartilage and bone development in MPS IVA, leading to systemic skeletal dysplasia, but does not evaluate chondroitin as a therapeutic intervention.
population_specificity: Patients with Mucopolysaccharidosis IVA (MPS IVA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans, a major component of perineuronal nets (PNNs), control plasticity and their role in memory, aging, Alzheimer's disease, and drug addiction.
results_summary: The study found that chondroitin sulfate proteoglycans in PNNs play a critical role in controlling plasticity and are implicated in memory, aging, Alzheimer's disease, and drug addiction. PNN alterations during development may also contribute to synaptic pathology in psychiatric disorders like schizophrenia and autism.
population_specificity: Not specified (focus on CNS mechanisms in normal and disease states).
